column3: How-to-guide: Collaborating with executives in a pro-design world.
column9: Iram Mirza, Jannie Lai, Craig Villamor
column132: This panel includes designers, product managers, and executives from various industries. The discussion focuses on how designers can collaborate effectively with executives to create a design-driven strategy from concept to implementation.
column134: Collaborating with executives, designing with executives, design as a strategy
column138: This panel includes designers, product managers, and executives from various industries. The discussion focuses on how designers can collaborate effectively with executives to create a design-driven strategy from concept to implementation.

column3: Women in UX Leadership in Business
column9: Janaki Kumar, Dan Rosenberg, Catherine Courage, Janice Rohn, Lisa Kamm, Lisa Anderson, Christine Holsberry, Apala Lahiri Chavan
column132: The goal of this panel is to launch a dialog on women in UX leadership. Despite ongoing progress toward equality, women still haven’t reached significant representation in leadership positions in the high-tech industry. Is the field of User Experience an exception to this norm? Does the interdisciplinary nature of UX play a role in making it easier or more difficult for women in our field?  Does a career in UX, regardless of gender place a glass ceiling on upward mobility into “C” level positions?  Our accomplished panel of UX managers will share their professional journeys, their observations on advantages and disadvantages, and their advice for the next generation.
column134: Women, UX Management, UX Leadership, Feminism, Organizational design, Diversity
column138: The goal of this panel is to launch a dialog on women in UX leadership in business. Our panelists of women leaders will share their insights with the UX community.
column139: We changed the title to Women in UX Leadership in Business, since we did not have representation from academia.

column3: Material Interactions – From Atoms & Bits to Entangled Practices
column132: This panel addresses some of the core aspects of the theme “It’s the experience” for the CHI2012 conference by focusing on the materials that constitute the foundation for interaction with computers. We take a series of questions as a joint point of departure to consider the nature and character of “material interactions” in HCI. Specifically, we consider theoretical, critical and practical approaches to material interactions and how they inform/become useful to HCI. The panel will include position statements from the panelists as well as high-level audience participation. We envision a fun and intellectually stimulating panel moderated by Prof. Mikael Wiberg consisting of a number of scholars with a well-developed view on digital materialities to fuel a discussion on material interactions - from atoms & bits to entangled practices. These scholars include: Prof. Hiroshi Ishii, Prof. Paul Dourish, Daniela Rosner, Petra Sundström, Anna Vallgårda and Tobie Kerridge. This panel also features Mark Rolston, Chief Creative Officer at Frog design, Inc.

column138: This panel addresses some of the core aspects of the theme “It’s the experience” for CHI2012 by focusing on the materials that constitute the foundation for interaction with computers.
column139: Our panel proposal has been carefully revised in relation to the great feedback we received. In detail we have revised it as to make sure that the panel theme "material interactions" is more clear and that the structure of the panel will ensure that we manage to move the discussion forward on materiality in HCI.

column3: Hunting for Fail Whales: Lessons from Deviance and Failure in Social Computing
column9: Michael Bernstein, Michael Conover, Benjamin Mako Hill, Andres Monroy-Hernandez, Brian Keegan, Aaron Shaw, Sarita Yardi, R.Stuart Geiger, Amy Bruckman
column42: Berkman Center for Internet & Society, Harvard University
column54: Berkman Center for Internet & Society, Harvard University
column78: Berkman Center for Internet & Society, Harvard University
column132: Social computing technologies are pervasive in our work, relationships, and culture. Despite their promise for transforming the structure of communication and human interaction, the complex social dimensions of these technological systems often reproduce offline social ills or create entirely novel forms of conflict and deviance. This panel brings together scholars who study deviance and failure in diverse social computing systems to examine four design-related themes that contribute to and support these problematic uses: theft, anonymity, deviance, and polarization.

column134: Deviant behavior, norms, online communities, community standards, socio-technical systems
column135: The Document in Source (Word, LaTeX, etc...).pdf
column138: This panel discusses how social behaviors like theft, anonymity, deviance, and polarization contribute to both the failure and success in diverse online communities.
column139: Re-focus on 4 thematic areas, 2 panelists will lead 50 minute parallel sub-discussions for each themeatic area, followed by a 30 minute synthesis session.

column3: Indy R&D: Doing HCI Research off the Beaten Path
column132: This panel discusses independent research and development in HCI. We focus on possible models for Indy R&D operations, supporting infrastructures, practical methods, and taking advantage of academic skills in the transition. Panel participants have experience in several different models of funding, conducting, and disseminating results from independent research. We will provide the audience with practical tips to help them decide if Indy R&D is right for them, and if so, help them do it.
column133: The disposable academic: Why doing a PhD is often a waste of time. The Economist. December 16, 2010. http://www.economist.com/node/17723223
column134: Research, development, design, independent, start-up, Management
column135: The Document in Source (Word, LaTeX, etc...).doc
column138: Indy R&D is an accelerating practice combining real-world concerns with academic curiosity. We provide practical tips to help decide if it's right for you, and help you get started.
column139: We were requested to provide more focus for this panel, both in terms of speakers and topics. In order to do so we made two principal changes: \  \ 1) We replace Jon Kolko with Alicia Gibb. This will help the panel focus principally on the practices of young entrepreneurs who are doing independent research and development. \  \ 2) We placed more emphasis on giving audience members a practical how-to/to-do list. This idea was present in the original extended abstract and proposal, but not given enough emphasis. The pragmatic best practices that we have all picked up through experience will be the backbone of this panel. (This also works well with CHI's theme this year, no?)

column3: The Arts, HCI, and Innovation Discourse (Invited Panel)
column9: Jill Fantauzzacoffin, Joanna Berzowska, Ernest Edmonds, Ken Goldberg, D. Fox Harrell, Brian Smith
column14: Department of Digital Media, Georgia Institute of Technology
column26: Department of Design and Computational Arts, Concordia University
column42: Creativity and Cognition Studios, University of Technology, Sydney
column50: Berkeley Center for New Media, College of Engineering, and School of Information, University of California, Berkeley
column62: Comparative Media Studies Program, and Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column74: Office of Government Affairs, Rhode Island School of Design
column132: Although both HCI and innovation policy have a STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) basis, both also include trends that incorporate the arts. The purpose of this panel is to show how HCI/arts discourse and innovation policy/arts discourse inform each other. We then discuss with the audience how innovation initiatives configure programs and roles for artists and HCI professionals working in HCI/arts.

column138: This panel relates issues in HCI/arts to the larger innovation discourse in order to bring a fresh perspective to the STEM/arts divide.
column139: Based on the initial comments of the panel chairs, we expanded our panelist lineup to include a greater range of researchers/practitioners/leaders in this domain. We also changed the format of the body of the abstract into a narrative style which better explains the roles that the panelists have taken in the evolution of initiatives that support interdisciplinary digital arts and HCI. More citations were added to incorporate the richness of discourse. The citations are also meant as a resource for readers who would like to familiarize themselves with this discourse. \  \ The chairs had requested that we change the title to better reflect the content. We have discussed it amongst ourselves, but can't come up with a better title. The panel is about parallels between HCI/arts and contemporary innovation discourse, the way that contemporary innovation discourse can illuminate some HCI/arts issues, and how considering these issues up and down the innovation discourse - policy - initiatives - programs - research - work chain can also be helpful with respect to understanding them. We are open to title suggestions or a further critique of the current title.

column9: Jeffrey Bardzell, Shaowen Bardzell, Carl DiSalvo, William Gaver, Phoebe Sengers
